an3.71:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
an3.71:4.2: Then the wanderer Channa went up to Venerable Ānanda
an3.71:4.4: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
an3.71:4.6: “Reverend Ānanda, would you teach giving up greed, hate, and delusion?”
an3.71:5.1: “But what drawbacks have you seen, Reverend Ānanda, that you’d teach giving up greed, hate, and delusion?”
an3.71:6.1: “A greedy person, overcome by greed, intends to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They experience mental pain and sadness.
an3.71:6.2: When greed has been given up, they don’t intend to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They don’t experience mental pain and sadness.
an3.71:6.3: A greedy person does bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
an3.71:6.4: When greed has been given up, they don’t do bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
an3.71:6.5: A greedy person doesn’t truly understand what’s for their own good, the good of another, or the good of both.
an3.71:6.6: When greed has been given up, they truly understand what’s for their own good, the good of another, or the good of both.
an3.71:6.7: Greed is a destroyer of sight, vision, and knowledge. It blocks wisdom, it’s on the side of anguish, and it doesn’t lead to extinguishment.
an3.71:7.1: A hateful person makes choices that hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. … Hate is a destroyer of sight, vision, and knowledge; it blocks wisdom, it’s on the side of anguish, and it doesn’t lead to extinguishment.
an3.71:7.2: A deluded person, overcome by delusion, intends to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They experience mental pain and sadness.
an3.71:7.3: When delusion has been given up, they don’t intend to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They don’t experience mental pain and sadness.
an3.71:7.4: A deluded person does bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
an3.71:7.5: When delusion has been given up, they don’t do bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
an3.71:7.6: A deluded person doesn’t truly understand what’s for their own good, the good of another, or the good of both.
an3.71:7.7: When delusion has been given up, they truly understand what’s for their own good, the good of another, or the good of both.
an3.71:7.8: Delusion is a destroyer of sight, vision, and knowledge; it blocks wisdom, it’s on the side of anguish, and it doesn’t lead to extinguishment.
an3.71:7.9: This is the drawback we’ve seen in greed, hate, and delusion, and this is why we teach their giving up.”
an3.71:8.1: “But, reverend, is there a path and a practice for giving up this greed, hate, and delusion?”
an3.71:8.2: “But, reverend, is there a path and a practice for giving up this greed, hate, and delusion?”
an3.71:8.4: “It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
an3.71:8.5: right view, right motivation, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right samādhi.
an3.71:8.7: This is the path, this the practice, for giving up this greed, hate, and delusion.”
an3.71:8.8: “This is a fine path, a fine practice, for giving up greed, hate, and delusion.
an3.71:8.9: Just this much is enough to be diligent.”
